SENT.plain: Continuous electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring was used during 213 carotid endarterectomies in 157 patients to identify cerebral ischemia
General anesthesia was used for all patients
An intraluminal shunt was not used routinely, but was inserted in 23 operations when EEG abnormalities associated with ischemia appeared
EEG changes occurred in 31 operations (14.5 percent)
Four patterns of abnormal recordings were identified and are discussed
Six patients developed ischemic EEG changes in association with hypotension during endarterectomy
In two of these patients changes appeared with a blood pressure drop of only 20 mm
Four patients with internal carotid artery back pressures of 75 to 100 mm
Hg developed EEG abnormalities which disappeared after shunt insertion
Our experience emphasizes the value of continuous EEG monitoring in detecting inadequate cerebral perfusion
